thread.title: Morning MoneyBeat Europe: Global Selloff Continues
thread.title_full: Morning MoneyBeat Europe: Global Selloff Continues

title: Morning MoneyBeat Europe: Global Selloff Continues
text:
Please feel free to send this email to friends and colleagues and include this link so they can sign up to receive it for free too http://on.wsj.com/MoneyBeatEuropeSignup 
Follow us on Twitter @WSJMoneyBeat. 
European markets dove deeper into the red Tuesday after worries about China and slumping commodities rippled through global markets. 
"With most of the European indices only another awful session away from crossing the 20% decline mark, the flight to safety trade is certainly on this morning," said Jonathan Sudaria from London Capital Group in a morning note. 
Europe's selloff deepened after U.S. stocks fell to their lowest levels since late August on Monday. Federal Reserve speakers did little to settle nerves, sending mixed signals as New York Fed President William Dudley and San Francisco Fed President John Williams separately both said they expect to see a rate rise this year, while Chicago Fed President Charles Evans said a rate rise probably wouldn't be appropriate until well into 2016. 
The dour sentiment spilled over into Asian trade Tuesday, where Japan's Nikkei closed down more than 4%, wiping out gains for the year. Stocks in China and Australia were also punished by the continued rout in commodities, sparked by a collapse in Glencore shares on Monday. 
"There is a growing feedback loop between Glencore and the broader commodity trade," said Chris Weston at IG. "There is clearly a sustained and ferocious attack on its equity and it’s unclear whether this is a genuine view that the company is not going to be around in six months." 
Ahead Tuesday, while Fed officials debate the precise timing of the next U.S. rate rise, a new raft of eurozone data-- including economic sentiment and German CPI-- could add further pressure on the European Central Bank to ramp up its policy support. 
Watch for: Eurozone economic sentiment, business climate, industrial and consumer confidence; Germany preliminary CPI; U.K. consumer credit, mortgage lending, CBI distributive trades; U.S. consumer confidence; S&P/Case-Shiller house price index. 
Market Snapshot: FTSE 100 down 0.54%, CAC 40 down 0.49% and DAX down 0.31%. Nikkei closed Tuesday down 4.05%. Brent crude up 0.57% at $47.61. Gold down 0.46% at $1126.50. EUR/USD at $1.1253. Ten-year Treasury yield lower at 2.073%, Bund yield lower at 0.579%, Gilt yield lower at 1.647%. 
What You May Have Missed on MoneyBeat 
Energy Transfer Bulked Up on Banks to Win Williams: The bragging rights may be larger than the fees for many of the banks advising Energy Transfer Equity LP on its $32.6 billion deal to buy Williams Cos. 
Glencore’s Red Tide Hits U.S. Shore: Shoot first, aim later. That is often the way in markets and Monday proved no different, especially for financial stocks. 
Capitulation In Biotech? ETF Suffers Biggest One-Day Drop Since 2011: There’s blood in the streets, but nobody’s buying. 
Breaking Bad: Dow Drops 270 Points, S&P 500 Breaks 1900: Stocks are in free fall, as concerns about global growth continue to send investors hurrying for the exits. 
Valeant Plunges As House Dems Seek Subpoena Over Price Increases: More bad news for the beaten down pharmaceutical and biotechnology sectors. 
From The Wall Street Journal 
Investors Fall Out of Love With Deals: Corporate executives earlier this year were feeling the love from investors when they announced acquisitions. Now, some buyers are getting burned. 
Asian Shares Slide; Japan Gives Up Gains for Year: Markets across Asia plummeted Tuesday, with Japan shares wiping out gains for the year, as investors see few signs the spillover of China’s slowdown will abate. 
VW Faces Barrage of Litigation: Lawyers are moving to consolidate widespread litigation stemming from Volkswagen’s emissions-cheating scandal, drawing the German auto maker into a prolonged legal case expected to spur rafts of depositions and demands for billions of dollars in damages. 
Lid on Oil Prices Refuses to Budge: Oil bulls can’t catch a break. The long-awaited decline in U.S. oil output has begun, data show, but many investors and analysts are still waiting for prices to stage a sustained recovery. 
Fiat Chrysler Labor Contract in Doubt: Workers at several of Fiat Chrysler Automobiles factories have rejected a proposed labor contract, indicating the Italian-U.S. auto maker is having a tough time selling a four-year deal that raises wages but falls short of expectations. 
India’s Central Bank Cuts Key Interest Rate More Than Expected: India’s central bank Tuesday cut its key interest rate more than markets expected and for the fourth time this year amid optimism Indian inflation rates will remain low. 
Obama and Putin Clash Over Syria: President Barack Obama and his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin clashed publicly over how to resolve the conflict in Syria, in a showdown in front of the rest of the world’s leaders that added uncertainty to the burgeoning crisis in the Middle East. More from The Wall Street Journal
